algorithms.bodyText: The family Cotingidse, of South America, contains a number of fruit-eating birds, many of which are of most brilliant colours, while the plainer-coloured species are of great interest. Among these latter may be mentioned the Bell-birds and the extraordinary Umbrella Bird. The Cotingas are a group in which the males are very brilliant in colour, and it is somewhat remarkable that they are so very rarely imported alive to Europe. Of the Purple-throated Cotinga (Cotinga cayana) a pair, imported last August, were presented to the Zoological Society by Mr. Spedan Lewis, and were the first of their kind to be received by the Society and probably the first ever imported. The male of this pair did not thrive from the first and only survived a comparatively short time, the post mortem examination of its body revealing the presence of mycosis. The female, however, appears likely to do well The Purple-throated Cotinga occurs in Guiana, Amazona, and Eastern Ecuador, and, as can be seen from the accompanying illustra- tion, the male is a particularly beautiful bird. Like most fruit-eating species, it is not difficult to manage in captivity, and it seems a pity that this and other species of the genus are not more often imported.
algorithms.page: 114 Sydney Porter--Notes on the Birds of Dominica
algorithms.bodyText: The only other species of the genus that has been represented in the Zoological Gardens is the Banded Cotinga ( C . cincta ) from S.E. Brazil, in which the male has the upper parts and a band across the breast ultramarine blue, the under parts plum-coloured. D. S.-S.
algorithms.sectionHeader: NOTES ON THE BIRDS OF DOMINICA
algorithms.bodyText: There is a strange sinister atmosphere about Dominica, which some say is an evil spirit which broods over the island. But leaving native superstitions aside, it is a strange fact that on this lovely island very few seem to succeed, something happens, and in time the jungle swallows up again the efforts made by man. After nearly three hundred years, while most of the other West Indian Islands seem to prosper, this island remains almost as wild and mysterious as ever. It is certainly the wildest and the most impressive land I have ever seen, and its grandeur and beauty will remain a life-long impression. Dominica will ever seem as a dream, as one of those strange mysterious and lovely lands which we see only in our dreaming hours, and I shall always feel that there is nowhere else left to see, for in Dominica I have seen the world's nearest approach to Paradise. I lived in a remote part of the island for a time, about 8 miles from my nearest white neighbour, and penetrated far into the great silent forests, so that I had an unique opportunity of seeing parts of the island which are denied to the ordinary traveller. The number of indigenous species inhabiting the island, considering its size and luxuriant vegetation, is comparatively small and contains no species of great interest to the scientific ornithologist except the two very rare and indigenous Parrots and the supposedly extinct Capped Petrel ((Estrelata hcesitata). Several beautiful and interesting species have, alas, been exterminated, including the beautiful Macaw (Ara guadaloupensis). The lack of species is made up for by the large numbers of each individual species, for birds are exceedingly abundant, especially the smaller ones. The two Parrots are very rare, one exceedingly so, and are in grave danger of extermination. It is a great
Sydney Porter--Notes on the Birds of Dominica

tragedy, as I have remarked before, that these two birds should be sought after as food ; for, strange to say, there is no systematic persecution of the other smaller birds, and I think that few, if any, are killed except the Pigeons and Doves, and the smaller birds such as the Humming-birds, Finches, etc., a,re looked upon with great favour by both black and white. Strange to say, there seem to be very few sea-birds around the coast of Dominica ; I have never seen any beyond an occasional Booby or Yellow-billed Tropic Bird fishing out at sea. These birds look strangely unlike the other sea-birds with their long pointed tails flowing behind and their beautiful plumage which shines like white satin in the sun. Most of my bird-watching was done in a beautiful valley surrounded almost all round by towering cliffs covered with the most luxuriant tropical vegetation ; giant tree ferns, slender palms, and huge forest trees ; it looked like an enormous crater, which, of course, it wasn't. There was an opening on to the seashore, but this was blocked up by a barrage of tall mangrove trees and graceful coconut-palms, and here and there through a rift in the foliage one could see the indescribable blue of the Caribbean Sea. The main part of this valley had been a lime plantation, but the dread disease which has killed Dominica's principal industry had visited it and killed all the trees. Needless to say, it had been abandoned, but all the dead trees were now overgrown by tropical creepers, and every- where rank vegetation had sprung up as it is wont to do on all cultivated lands which have been abandoned. The place had evidently been swampy, and had been elaborately drained by means of channels, but these were now filled up with huge aquatic plants, and the whole place was reverting to its original condition. Birds always seem to flock to old cultivated lands, for, instead of a pure culture of certain plants and trees as there often is in a wild state, there is an enormously varied growth of vegetation, each particular growth trying to gain ascendancy, and I believe this is conducive to an enormous amount of insect life ; at all events, it was a birds' paradise, and nearly every species, except the two rare Parrots, seemed to be there. Different species of Herons and Kingfishers fished in the swamps, which were
algorithms.page: 116 Sydney Porter--Notes on the Birds of Dominica
algorithms.bodyText: also inhabited by Pipits and Sandpipers, while Warblers of dozens of species simply swarmed in the undergrowth, especially the exquisite little American Warblers, Dominica being one of then- winter homes. I spent many happy hours there with not a soul to disturb my peace, the only sounds being the roar of the sea and the song of the birds. What a lovely and quiet haven it was ! The Dominican Honey-Creeper (Ccereba dominicano ).--This lovely little creature is exceedingly common on the island, and its short harsh song is one of the best known bird sounds around the houses or in the depths of the bush ; but the birds are not found in the forests, which are singularly destitute of bird life except for the two indigenous Parrots and a few Pigeons. It is remarkably tame and allows one to approach within a few yards of it whilst it is trilling with gusto its not very pleasant song. It is energy personified, and is continually on the move, dashing from one tree to another, hardly seeming to have time to feed or sing. There is a species of tree in Dominica which has flowers like those of the well-known " Bottle-brush 55 tree, but the flowers are white, and have an exquisite scent like a mixture of orange-blossom and heliotrope, and whenever one comes across one of these trees one is sure to see at least half a dozen of these tiny birds feeding upon the honey-laden blossoms. The bird takes hold of the flowers sideways (for they have no petals, but are composed of tufts of snowy white stamens), and sucks out the sweet juice. The birds are very business-like, and each keeps to his own part of the tree, and when one trespasses there is a sudden fracas and the intruder is driven away. This creeper is called the " robin " by the natives, why, I do not know, for a bird more unlike a Robin is hard to imagine ; it is more like a Humming-bird, but possibly it is because it is so familiar. I think that this bird must outnumber the other birds of the island by two to one, excepting the Black-faced Grassfinch. The males are terribly pugnacious, and when two meet they are bound to fight. I have often nearly picked up two combatants which have been locked together in each other's claws. In colour this tiny mite is blue-black above and bright yellow below, and with very
Sydney Porter--Notes on the Birds of Dominica

conspicuous white eyebrow streaks. It feeds upon minute insects as well as the nectar of flowers. The Helmet-crested Humming-bird (Bellona exilis). -- Without a doubt the gem of the avifauna of the island ; an exquisite creature, looking like some brilliant iridescent emerald insect as it buzzes from flower to flower in search of the tiny insects, etc., which are to be found in most of the nectar-bearing blossoms. I have never seen in any bird such a brilliant shining iridescent green as this bird's crest is, in fact, it looks like a bright green flame on the bird's head, and this is set off by the intense black colour of the body feathers. It is not lacking in intelligence, despite its diminutive size, for it is the tiniest of the West Indian Humming-birds ; if it sees a stranger it alights on a slender twig and shows the greatest interest in his where- abouts, until another bird of the same species appears in the vicinity, when a violent battle is at once commenced, in fact the movements of the combatants are too rapid to be followed by the human eye. No bird is more pugnacious than this tiny mite, he will attack birds twenty times his own size, especially Hawks, and even a male and female cannot meet without a slight difference of opinion. Like the proverbial Irishman, if there is a row he will be there. I have noticed the little hummers busily engaged around the flowers, when suddenly they have heard the sound of a fight, and they have gone off in the direction like the shot from a gun. Sometimes when two of the little quarrelsome honey-creepers have been fighting, one of these Humming- birds has appeared on the scene and at once dispersed the two combatants. In seeing and studying Humming-birds for the first time I found that I have been under a delusion, firstly that they spent all their time in the air buzzing from flower to flower, and secondly that they can be approached and watched as they feed as easily as one watches bees. Both ideas I found to be erroneous in regard to the Humming-birds of Dominica. One usually sees them on a bush or on a slender twig of a tree, where they sit sunning themselves or preening their feathers, and the little Bellona exilis. like the others, spends much of its time in searching the clusters of leaves for minute insects. I have
algorithms.address: 118 Sydney Porter--Notes on the Birds of Dominica
algorithms.bodyText: often seen them go over a whole tree making a most systematic and careful search. One little fellow I used to see every evening on a special branch of a lime-tree, where he sang his evensong, which sounded more like the song of a cricket than that of a bird. I think that this bird is the most marvellous living creature, a minute atom of life not much larger than a bumble-bee, yet in every way as perfect an organism as any living bird, and mo're intelligent than a good many. I have seen these tiny creatures flitting about the flowers in a rain- storm w r hich would have beaten many larger birds to the ground ; perhaps these birds manage to avoid the drops ! Around my window grew a purple creeper, and every morning one of these Hummers would come and, hanging on invisible wings, would probe every tiny flower. Sometimes the bird would appear black, like any ordinary humble-bee, then he would turn and the sun would throw up the marvellous prismatic colours, until it appeared like some brilliant glowing phosphorescent gem. The female, who is even smaller than the male, is more of a brown colour, and the crest is not so large or brilliant. The Garnet-throated Humming-bird (Eulampis jugularis ).--This is a large, but exceedingly beautiful Humming-bird, and around Roseau, the tiny capital of the island, it is very common. Though at least four times the size of the Crested Humming-bird described above, it is often routed and put to flight by this tiny upstart. I saw many of these Humming-birds in the botanical gardens, where this species is particularly numerous. They are often to be seen sunning themselves, sitting on some slender twig, moving first this way and then that to get the rays of the sun on the whole of their plumage. The iridescence of the bird's plumage, when the rays of the sun catch it, is indescribable. At first sight to a stranger this bird appears to be black, and many people, strangers to the island, have told me how disappointed they have been in the Humming-birds of Dominica because they were black. When flying both this and the other three species appear to be black, but when seen at close quarters it can boast of few rivals in the avian world, even in this wonderful family.
Sydney Portei--Notes on the Birds of Dominica

At one time the skins of this bird and the other Humming-birds were in great demand in America, and the natives lost no time in supplying the demand, with the consequence that no Humming-birds were to be seen for a long time, but the exportation of the skins was forbidden, and now they are almost as plentiful as ever. I have always noticed that Humming-birds fold their wings below the tail, and not above as other birds do. The food of this bird is mainly insects. Emerald-throated Humming-bird (Eulampis holosesiceus ).-- A most lovely creature of a glittering emerald green colour. It is about intermediate in size between the other two ; it is also the plainest in colour. It is the most familiar and the easiest to observe. One usually sees it perched in some conspicuous spot, and from there it takes short excursions to the nearest flowers, which it probes whilst hanging on seemingly invisible wings. Sometimes, after a rain-storm, I have seen it behaving like some mechanical toy, flying up and down with the greatest rapidity above the bushes, apparently catching the tiny flies which had taken shelter under the leaves. The rain on the bird's plumage gives a most wonderful prismatic effect, and the bird seems to glow with every known colour ; I have noticed the same effect on the plumage of some of the sunbirds after they have had a bath. There is a peculiar tuft of long white feathers beneath each wing. I have only seen these tufts when the bird scratches its head, the leg being brought up from behind the wing brings these feathers out so that they fall over the wing ; doubtless they are used in the display. In the very heart of the great tropical forests whence I went in search of the rare Dominican Parrots, where subdued green twilight always reigned, we found this little gem. It appeared quite fearless, and buzzed about searching the heads of the low tree-ferns and other plants in search of insects. I saw it long after the twilight had fallen when I could hardly tell whether it was a beetle or a bird. It seems strange to see these tiny creatures here, for one usually associates Humming-birds with tropical sunshine and gaudy flowers. In fact, I have seen this bird feeding more upon the insects which it finds among the leaves of the trees rather than by sipping the nectar of the
algorithms.address: 120 Sydney Porter--Notes on the Birds of Dominica
algorithms.bodyText: flowers. It seems to favour the mangrove-trees, and I have seen individuals perched upon the leaves feeding upon some kind of tiny insect or blight. This tiny creature, like its congener, the Helmet-crested Humming- bird, is not wanting in courage in spite of its size, for I have seen it attack a Buzzard which was sitting preening itself in the sun. The Buzzard took very little notice of the tiny creature which buzzed about its head, for it evidently knew the futility of trying to catch such an agile antagonist. Bell's Humming-bird.-- Like the last bird, this very rare and indigenous species is found only in the depths of the mountain forests. When in search of the Imperial Parrot I was astonished to find this bird buzzing about the low undergrowth in the semi-twilight in the gloomy forest. It seemed like some tiny green wraith floating about until some ray of sunshine which managed to penetrate the gloom fell like a searchlight upon the bird and made it appear like a glowing opal. It seems to feed upon the tiny insects which it procures from the heads and leaves of the plants which form the undergrowth in the forests. The Two-coloured Humming-bird (Cyanophaia hicolor). -- This bird is rare, and I have seen it but few times. It is a fair-sized Humming-bird, the under parts being jet black and the upper parts the well known Humming-bird green, but the whole of the wing coverts are an amazingly brilliant emerald green which flashes and glistens in the sunlight. The only times I have seen this bird have been at a tiny native settlement called Calibishie, on the Atlantic coast, where I observed it sucking nectar from the banana-flowers. The Rufous-crowned Warbler (Dendroica ruficapitta ).--One of the commonest and yet at the same time one of the most beautiful of the Warblers to be found in Dominica. This tiny golden bird is to be seen everywhere. One usually meets with them chasing each other, not playfully, but in hot pursuit, and when the pursuer catches his quarry there is a terrific fight, in which both birds fall to the ground an animated ball of golden feathers.
Sydney Porter--Notes on the Birds, of Dominica

This bird looks like a glorified Zosterops, for it has the same rotund appearance ; its habits are almost identical. The embodiment of perpetual motion, it spends all its time in search of minute insects which constitute its main food. The general colour of this lovely bird is bright golden yellow, the male having the top of the head a rich golden orange. American Redstart (Setophaga ruticilla). -- America is happy in possessing a large number of exquisite Warblers, which differ from the Warblers of the old world in being smaller and much more beautifully coloured, red, pink, and yellow being the predominating colours. Of the whole family, none is more lovely than the bird known as the American Redstart, a bird which has no relationship to the birds known as Redstarts in Europe, the American Redstart being a Warbler and the European Redstart a Chat. This little Warbler is to my mind not only the most beautiful of the American Warblers, but the loveliest of all the known Warblers. It is a migrant to Dominica during the winter months, though I believe that a few stragglers remain all the year round. Its habits resemble those of the other small Warblers. It is ever active in its ceaseless search for small insects. I am sure that owing to the presence of so many Warblers in the West Indies insect pests, with the exception of mosquitos and sandflies, are conspicuous by their absence. Perhaps I may be forgiven for quoting from The Booh of Birds , issued by the National Geographic Society of America concerning this bird. " Its beauty of form and plumage and its graceful motions place this dainty bird at the head of our list of Wood Warblers--a place of distinction indeed. The bird appears to be the incarnation of animated motion and fairly dances its way through the forest. " Spanish imagination has coined a suggestive and fitting name for the Redstart, ' Candelita ' little torch-bearer.' The full appropriate- ness of the name appears as the graceful creature flits through the greenery, displaying the salmon-coloured body and the bright wing and tail patches." This delightful creature is clad in a combination of colours seldom seen in a bird--a beautiful orange-salmon, yellow, red and brown, the
algorithms.address: 122 Sydney Porter--Notes on the Birds of Dominica
algorithms.bodyText: hen lacks the salmon shade, which is replaced by a dull yellow. It is certainly one of the most attractive of the smaller birds to be seen in Dominica. When sailing several hundred miles off the coast of Florida quite a few of these fragile wanderers came on board in a state of utter exhaustion and starvation, it was pathetic to see them making a desperate search for insects in all the nooks and crannies on the ship with, of course, no avail. We caught several with the hope of saving their lives, placing them in a cage in a warm room and feeding them on cockroaches, but it was of no avail, they all died in a few hours. The sea must take a terrible toll of these fragile mites and also the other tiny American Warblers when migrating to their Northern home. I have seen dozens of these tiny and exquisite creatures beaten down by the rain as they vainly tried to reach a resting place on the ship. To me it is the greatest of all mysteries how these tiny creatures manage to cross thousands of miles of ocean and arrive safely at their destination. I am sure that a good percentage must find a watery grave. Black and White Warbler (Mniotilta varia). -- This is a bird that would meet the most unobservant eye ; its plumage, though boasting of no brilliant colours, is a very striking arrangement of black and white. It is not a common bird, but unusually tame and confiding, allowing one to watch it from a distance of a few feet. Its behaviour reminds one of that of a Tree-creeper for it is wonderfully agile, running up and down the branches and stems of dead trees searching the bark for minute insects, or flitting from one clump of undergrowth to another, disappearing for a minute or two only to reappear as it flies to the next bush or tangle of undergrowth. It is not a resident of the West Indies, but a migrant from Eastern North America. Plumbeous Warbler (Dendroica plumbea). -- Slate-grey, lighter above, the greater and lesser wing-coverts edged with white and a white- eyebrow stripe, is the colour of this bird. It is another of the tiny and dainty American Warblers, but unlike its brethren it boasts of no striking colours. It is tame and confiding and seems to take no notice of human beings, as it searches the undergrowth for insects. It is a common bird in the island but, owing to its plain garb, goes unnoticed by the crowd.
Sydney Porter--Notes on the Birds of Dominica

Dominican Kingbird or Tyrant (Tyrannus dominicensis). -- The Tyrants, as we call them in England, are the most characteristic birds of the West Indies, and usually the first birds to catch the eye of the newcomer. The Dominican Tyrant invariably selects some very conspicuous position such as the top of a dead tree or a telegraph pole, and from there it makes regular short excursions after passing insects upon which it feeds exclusively. They remind me more of Bee-eaters in their habits than of any other birds I know, though these birds will sometimes pick an insect from off the ground, whereas a Bee-eater will never do this. These birds are extraordinarily tame, the reason being, I suppose, that they meet with no persecution but are encouraged owing to their insect-destroying propensities. One bird I used to watch every day whose favourite perch was on a telegraph wire about a yard away from my window, and from early morning until night he remained there. I have watched the birds catch young lizards, frogs and young land-crabs. These it would batter for a considerable time on the branch of a tree, and even when they appeared to be smashed to pulp the bird would have great difficulty in swallowing them. On a huge and venerable tree which was almost dead from old age, but few leaves remaining on its rotting branches, and which stood near the house, the birds held a morning concert and entertainment. About a dozen or more birds would gather, and spreading themselves about on the topmost branches, would begin. They would begin by singing in chorus their by no means pleasant song, meanwhile opening and closing their wings and tails with the same automatic motion as that of those toy birds which are sold by street vendors in London. Sometimes a tournament would take place, two birds rising high in the air in a mock fight, the rest shrieking their approval of this performance, and as soon as the two birds descended, two more would start. This entertainment would last about an hour, during which time the hubhub would be terrific, and after this they would leave, one by one, to take up the duties of the day. Ober's Crested Flycatcher (Myiarchus oheri oberi ).--This bird very much resembles the Dominican Tyrant. In the colour of its plumage, size and habits, it has the same arrangement of colours, but
algorithms.page: 124 Sydney Porter--Notes on the Birds of Dominica
algorithms.bodyText: is very slightly smaller and paler, looking like a washed-out edition of its larger cousin. It is not nearly so common as the other bird, and is rather local and usually found in pairs. Despite its name, it appears to me to be a true Tyrant. Martinique Flycatcher (Elainia pagana martinica ).--This bird is a true Flycatcher, but looks very much like a Warbler ; in fact its habits seem to resemble those of a Warbler rather than those of a Flycatcher. It seems to frequent the bushes and trees rather than take up its stand in some conspicuous spot, as is the habit of the other Flycatchers. At first sight it looks very much like a hen Chaffinch, but it has a large loose crest of white feathers which is concealed when in repose. It is a very common bird, and is, I think, a resident of the island. It is very tame, and has a lovely full sweet song, which it is fond of uttering. The Dominican Wren.-- The Wren of Dominica is a lovely little creature whose confiding habits and extraordinary sweet song endear it to all human beings. It is of a much more slender build than the European Wren, but its habits are somewhat similar; it is somewhat local and frequents the environs of the country houses, where it builds its nest under the eaves or in some crack or cranny of the house. Sclater's or the Red-throated Finch (Loxigilla noctis sclateri).-- On nearly all the West Indian islands are found different sub-species of this bird, and they differ but slightly from each other. It is an exceedingly common bird in Dominica, but a little gem for all that. It takes the same place there as the Sparrow at home. Tame and confiding, it is found in every garden, and when encouraged, will come into the houses. A friend of mine encouraged these charming little birds to come into her house, but soon had reason to repent of her action ; they hopped about the table pecking at the fruit and spoiling it, bathed in the finger-bowls as soon as they were put on the table, and became such a nuisance that they had to be excluded from the house altogether. The cock is jet black except for his bright red bib, but his mate is a very sombre and inconspicuous little creature of a mouse-grey colour.

Sydney Portei--Notes on the Birds of Dominica 125 The male reminds me, more than any other bird I have seen, of a dull edition of the Scarlet-chested Sunbird of Central Africa. I quite fell in love with these charming birds and was sorely tempted to bring some back to Europe, for I could quite easily have captured some, but having five of the very rare Parrots from the island, which were the main object of my visit, I felt that I couldn't be burdened with more birds, especially as I had other countries to visit. The nest, which is a very untidy structure, looking like a ball of rubbish thrown into the tree, is composed mainly of strands of banana- leaves. Often it is slung below the branch of an evergreen-tree, the inside is, however, beautifully woven and lined with feathers and down, and the entrance is quite concealed. The eggs are four to five in number and are very like those of the European Hedge Sparrow, but rather smaller in size, and perhaps a slightly paler blue. In size and shape this bird is very much like a Bullfinch, but its habits resemble those of a Sparrow in so much that it is usually found around human habitations, feeding upon the crumbs or upon the tiny seeds of weeds which it finds in the gardens. Its diet also includes small insects. I don't think that this species has ever been imported into this country, but it would be a very desirable acquisition to our aviaries. Black-bellied Grass Finch or Quit (Tiaris bicolor omissa). -- A near relation of the well-known Cuban Finch, a bird which it very much resembles, except that it lacks the yellow markings which makes it appear very dark, in fact, at a distance it seems almost black. It shares with the last mentioned bird the honour of being the commonest bird in the island. Around the native huts, farm buildings, and upon nearly all cultivated ground, one is sure to see flocks of these little creatures busily engaged in picking up minute seeds which form their main food. One thing in Dominica that struck me as being rather singular was that so many of the birds fed on flowers. These little birds were frequently to be seen in company with the Honey Creepers feeding upon the small flowers of various trees. This Grass Finch always reminds me of a miniature Sparrow, which has been dipped in soot, in fact, I think that they are rather ugly little birds. The hens, though quite drab little birds in colouring, look much brighter and cleaner.

Guadeloupe Grosbeak (Saltator guadelujpensis). -- This verv striking looking bird, which is nearly as large as a Thrush, is usually seen in pairs frequenting the abandoned lime plantations or around the country houses. It reminds one of a large and sombre looking Cardinal, being of a greyish colour below and a dark moss-green above, with white markings. It is usually very quiet and unobtrusive, slipping about in a kind of apologetic way as though it had no business to be there at all. It seems to feed principally upon the leaves of certain trees. I have frequently watched birds feeding for fifteen minutes or so, stowing away enormous quantities of the leaves of a certain creeper. I have also seen them feeding upon the large white unripe seeds of cannas, which are as large as peas. This Grosbeak has a very loud sweet song, very similar to that of a
algorithms.figure: Blackbird. {To be continued.) TROGONS By Karl Plath
algorithms.bodyText: Mr. Porter's article in the March number about the Quezal was very interesting and I, too, have often wondered why this wonderful bird was not more generally known in aviculture. In my opinion it is the most beautiful and gorgeous of all known birds, even excelling the Birds of Paradise, whose gorgeous feather ornamentation is so often grotesque. The Quezal's flowing wing and tail coverts are more in keeping with the harmony and grace of line of beautiful bird-form-- though the rich colours and extravagant plumage of the Birds of Paradise often make one gasp at their beauty. I venture to correct Mr. Porter's statement of the texture of the tail-plumes as being similar to the plumes of the Great Bird of Paradise. I would say that they are more like those outer half-barbed feathers on the Peacocks' train. About two years ago we had as a guest at one of the meetings of the Chicago Ornithological Society, a gentleman (whose name I unfortunately do not now recall) who was doing Government work in the Republic of Salvador. He spoke of the Quezal as being far from

Captain Reginald Waud--Notes from Bradley Court 127 uncommon there. Mr. Crandall, of the New York Zoological Society, also tells of a man in Costa Rica who kept a pair of them for several months in the patio of his home, and because they were so " dirty " finally released them ! I do not think the Quezal would be difficult in aviculture if its nature is at all like that of the Cuban Trogon, and I believe all Trogons are similar in disposition. I have had a Cuban Trogon for three years now, and it has always been in good health, and for the last year has maintained its beautiful plumage. It is quite fearless, and can always be depended on to " perform " for visitors (come to my fingers for mealworms, of which it is exceedingly fond). I had at first what I am sure was a true pair, for though exactly alike in appearance (most birds of this family are quite different in sexual plumage) their voices were noticeably different in pitch and they frequently called to one another. The female had a higher-pitched voice and only lived a year, and for a long time after the male never uttered a note. A third bird received at the same time was sick on arrival, but lingered on for several months. All three of these birds were in very rough plumage on arrival. Ever since I have been trying to get a mate for my bird, but no more have been imported. I think that it would not be difficult to breed them as they seem quite oblivious to other birds, and shortly before the female died, both seemed interested in a hollow log.

A few notes concerning my aviaries may be of interest to some readers, so I send them with apologies. I have bred Shanahs two years running, and I find the best method is to put the cock and hen together in May in an outdoor aviary. During the winter I keep them separate, but always in cages adjoining, so that they can see each other ; in this way I find one is not so troubled by their fighting. When they are paired and the hen goes to nest, and about two or three days before the eggs are due to hatch, I open the outside door of the aviary and let them loose in the garden, always
algorithms.address: 128 Captain Reginald Waud--Notes from Bradley Court
algorithms.bodyText: being careful to feed inside the aviary, and shut them up at night for fear of Owls and stray cats. This I find not only very advantageous, as they find so much live food themselves for the young, but also they are most attractive flying about from bush to bush and shooting up their tails on any branch or the lawn when they alight. They are quite capable of taking care of themselves against any other birds, and always drive the Thrushes or Blackbirds away from anywhere near the aviary. They also get very tame when at liberty and will fly after me wherever I go, hoping for a mealworm or leather] acket, and have no fear of human beings. Before I let them out I found it extremely difficult to rear any young ; after a few days they would throw the young ones out of the nest and, of course, kill them ; but after I let them out I had no trouble in that direction. It is most amusing to watch them flying into the eaves of the house and catching spiders, blue-bottles or any stray moth, etc. I regret to say I lost my old hen in the autumn through moulting, and I fear old age. I certainly had her for years. I have now got a new hen, and am hoping to have good luck with her this year. In my birdroom at the present moment (the 24th March) I have a pair of Blossom-head Parrakeets nesting in a cage 3 ft. 6 in. by 18 in. and 3 ft. high. I noticed in February the cock feeding the hen, and saw she wished to go to nest, so I put in a box, with a round hole at one end, and put some sawdust in it; she immediately took possession. I have a small door at one end, whereby I can look into the box. I did so on the 22nd March, when she was off feeding, and found she had laid two eggs ; since then I have not disturbed her again, and shall simply have to wait until I hear sounds of young birds. Surely this is somewhat unique for Blossom-heads to nest in a cage. My birds were frightfully wild, and used to fly about the cage the moment one approached, but after they began to nest they have settled down in a marvellous manner, and now never have any fear of any human being, taking even no notice of my Hawkhead Parrot, who has never been caged since I had him, and flies all over the Park or wherever he likes, always returning to the birdroom in the afternoon for food, and roosting on the top of the Blossom-head's cage. My Hawkhead is a delightful person, and full of character. One afternoon about 4 p.m.
algorithms.title: Avicultural Notes
algorithms.bodyText: I watched him go for a small Owl who was sitting on a barn near by. The Hawkhead flew on to the barn, threw up his crest, and the little Owl flew off in terror. I should like to say I had great trouble in procuring a hen Blossom-head, as they are hardly ever imported, as a rule only cocks arriving. This one I got through the kindness of Mr. Ezra, who was able to get one for me, and I am extremely grateful to him. .

Members of the Society will, on 31st May, have an opportunity of seeing the wonderful collection of foreign birds at Foxwarren Park. It has never been so complete as it is at present, containing as it does an almost endless number of rarities. There are several birds brought by M. Delacour from Indo- China which have never before been seen alive in Europe. The new Parrakeet aviaries are also very well worth Inspection and the inmates are mostly breeding. An interesting experiment that is being tried by Mr. Ezra consists of the liberation of Cattle Egrets. ' These were at first kept in one of the aviaries and, as I write, three or four have been liberated but have not gone away. It is intended to let out others in the hope of establishing a breeding colony at liberty. The new Parrot House at the Zoo is now stocked and open to the public, and amongst the rarities to be seen are a Duyvenbode's Lory, a Racquet-tailed Parrot, and an example of the rare Geoffroy us cyanicollis, all in perfect plumage. We must heartily congratulate Mr. A. H. Isenberg of Menlo Park, California, on his successful breeding of Donaldson's Touraco described in Aviculture for April, 1930. Mr. Isenberg appears to possess some beautiful aviaries, and he is fortunate in living in a climate very

Correspondence favourable to the keeping and breeding of foreign birds. The nest was built in a living poplar-tree at about nine feet from the ground. Four young appear to have been reared from three nests, the normal clutch of eggs being two. The young birds " began eating by themselves when only a few days out of the nest. It took about ten weeks before they began looking like their parents, up to which time they were a very dark grey, their heads and necks covered with dark fuzz, their bills were nearly black at first, gradually changing to red." Mr. Isenberg tells us that the Touracos during the breeding season were very troublesome in the aviary, ruthlessly attacking the other inmates. While feeding the young they ate hard-boiled egg readily and were often seen on the lawn searching for worms, but otherwise had only fruits and berries, being specially fond of grapes. Donaldson's Touraco was described by Sharpe in 1895 from specimens collected by Dr. Donaldson Smith as Turacus donaldsoni, but it is now known to be a sub-species of T. leucotis, so that its correct name is Turacus leucotis donaldsoni, or Donaldson Smith's White-eared Touraco. It is noticeable that most of the writers in Aviculture who have succeeded in breeding birds to any extent reside in California where the climate is ideal for aviculture and it is very satisfactory to find how enthusiastically it is being taken up there. Aviculture seems to be prospering to a certain extent in Australia also, and I feel sure that in these countries it would be possible to save species of birds that are threatened with extinction by breeding them in captivity.
Sir, --We bought two pairs of Holds last year in good condition, and apparently perfect save that one cock has a crooked toe. On arrival they were paired off and housed separately. One pair settled
algorithms.figure: Correspondence
algorithms.bodyText: down amicably, but the cock with the crooked toe was so henpecked and terrorized that the hens were changed over in the hope of securing him a less harried existence. But again pair No. 1 proved friendly, or at any rate indifferent to each other, and hen No. 2 persecuted the cock so savagely that to save his life he was taken away and passed the winter by himself. Another attempt was made this spring ; the unattached hen who was being bullied by pair No. 1 was kept for some days side by side with the single cock, who, I may say, showed all the signs of wanting a mate. As long as the partition was between them they seemed friendly, but as soon as they came together the hen turned so viciously on him that she would certainly have killed him if they had not been parted. As before, he fled terrified without making the least attempt to defend himself although he is a fine well-developed bird and boasts a good pair of spurs. Can you or your readers explain this curious state of things ? E. E. Chawner.
algorithms.sectionHeader: AN EARLY BLACKCAP AND A LATE BRAMBLING
algorithms.bodyText: Sir, --I had a good view of a fine Cock Blackcap on the morning of 3rd April. The weather was dull and cold, and he was silent. Usually one hears this species before seeing it--either a fragment of song or a harsh alarm note. It is the earliest date I have recorded in this part of the country, and my observations cover a number of years. On the 5th of April, while watching a Lesser Spotted Woodpecker-- an unusual visitor to our garden--a small group of Chaffinches flew up from some low ground a considerable distance away. One of them appeared to have an unusually dark head and on closer investigation it proved to be a Cock Brambling. The distinctive white patch above the tail was plainly noticeable when it flew off. One can by this means distinguish them from Chaffinches at quite a long distance. I do not remember having seen one so late as this before. Hamilton Scott. Ipswich.
algorithms.sectionHeader: Correspondence A RING-NECKED PARRAKEET AT LIBERTY
algorithms.bodyText: Sir, --Eor the last six weeks--that is, since the beginning of February--there has been frequenting our garden and the neighbouring ones a cock Indian Ring-necked Parrakeet, obviously one of those turned loose by some foolish but callous individual during the psittacosis scare. Fortunately, belonging to a hardy species, he has managed to get a living all through the bad weather--in fact, he looks in very good trim. He occasionally comes on the top of the aviaries, but never makes any attempt to get in or seems at all anxious about the seed which he can see inside, and so far he has taken none offered. One of his favourite trees now is a very large Prunus pissardi (purple-leaved plum) which within the next few days will be a sheet of white blossoms. In the morning sunlight he looks very beautiful, swinging himself about in the upper twiggy branches, hanging upside down with open wings. But the destruction ! Buds and small twigs falling everywhere. To-day his name is " Mud " with the gardener. Large groups of polyanthus growing in the grass in the orchard have been stripped of their blossoms. " Sparrows," said I, when shown them. " No," said my man, " they have been ' cottoned ' for weeks, and not a Sparrow has touched them so far." The Ring-neck had been seen walking in the grass not many yards away, but nobody saw him touch the plants--so he is not proved guilty yet. But I am afraid he is the culprit. After seeing the damage this bird can do--I have not mentioned the colossal number of buds of plum and pear taken from his two favourite trees. I wonder how the fruit-trees fare on the estates of those aviculturists who have a number of birds at liberty. But, of course, all Parrakeets are not so destructive as Ring-necks or Alexandrines. Hamilton Scott. 21 th March. EGG-BINDING Sir, --I read with interest Mrs. Dewar Murray's letter in your January number recommending Cimicefuga Racemosa 3x potency for egg-binding. I have a hen Ribbon Finch who got egg-bound
algorithms.figure: Correspondence
algorithms.bodyText: with her second egg some weeks ago. Last week, in much colder weather, she started to lay again. I had given her three drops of the Cimicefuga Racemosa from the moment I saw r the cock carrying feathers about. She laid five eggs -without any trouble. We had deep snow three nights, and once I noticed the thermometer dropped in the night from 50 to 40 degrees. I am now trying it for a hen Cordon Bleu, who is very ill with every egg, and I have to keep a fire going all night and really nurse her. She lays soft eggs. I have tried grit and mortar rubble, and soil and iodine, but I cannot get her right. Each egg takes 24 hours to come. Can any member suggest anything at all that I can do ? She is tame, and hops into the hospital cage quite happily, and as soon as the bad time is over is well and happy again, and sings and calls for her mate. C. M. Irvine.

Sir,-- In your notes on last summer you remark that the dry atmosphere was not congenial to insect life, and that Pheasant-breeders report a large preponderance of cock birds. I fancy that there is a relation between the two facts. During the years 1926-8 I reared twenty-two Quail in my aviaries, only one out of all those was a hen. When thinking it over I fancied it might have been caused through my not giving the parents any live insect food until the eggs were hatched. Years ago I had a pair of Chinese Painted Quail, which I largely fed on mealworms and killed all their chicks except two before I found out my mistake ; those two were hens. The only Quail-like birds which hatched out last year were Turnix ypugnax. I had given them a few mealworms daily all through the winter, until I could get ants' eggs and gentles ; during the summer the cock was so wild that he would not incubate properly. In despair I put the pair in quite a small aviary, hoping that they would be tame enough another year. Then one day in October I discovered two half-grown chicks, both these are hens. The above results may be onfy a chance. I should like to know' what other members think. H, L. Sigh,

Sir, --I have a pair of Hanging Parrots which I don't find described in Lord Tavistock's book. The male is about 6 inches in length, and has the throat and forehead red. The top of the head is orange-tan, abruptly terminated on the nape with a narrow band of red. The upper back is tinged with golden. The female is considerably smaller, and I am not at all sure that she is of the same species. She has the red forehead, but the red on throat of the cock is replaced by a similar large patch of paler green. Her cheeks are blue. My Spix Macaw is becoming more lovable every day--talks quite a bit, but not always distinctly in a feminine voice, and frequently bursts into song--in a laughably quavering manner. It is very tame and can be trusted to remain on its perch unchained. The perch has an addition of a branch about 2 feet high. Among new arrivals in the aviary are perfect specimens of the Golden Tanager (T. arthusi), Philippine Button Quail, which are very tame, Blue Solitaire, which started to sing the day after arrival, and a splendid pair of Western Bluebirds (Sialia mexicana occidentals). These differ from Sialia sialia sialis by having all the throat blue and a small patch of chestnut on the back. I hope to breed them. My collection includes from one to four each of the following birds, all living in harmony together, excepting the Macaw and Parrakeets, which, of course, are kept separately. My oldest bird is a female Liothrix, which I have had over eleven years. I have just lost my
algorithms.table: Black-headed Sugarbird, which lived in the aviary seven years : Liothrix , Silver-eared Mesia, Blue Tanager, Brazilian Scarlet Tanager, Red-head Tanager ( Pyranga ), Cuban Tanager, Cedar Waxwings,

algorithms.sectionHeader: THE ORIGIN OF COLOUR VARIETIES IN BUDGERIGARS
algorithms.bodyText: Sir, --I feel I must write and thank Dr. H. Duncker and Consul- General Cremer for their extremely interesting letter on the above subject. I was rather afraid that the first mutations having taken place so long ago, it would be difficult to get any record of them, but the very excellent account of what must have happened given by these gentlemen makes up for it. As to future colours, I foresee there may be difficulty in obtaining accurate information. Anyone producing a new colour would most likely be inclined to keep the means by which it was obtained a secret. This may be small-minded and selfish, but it is human nature. I wonder if it would be asking too much of such people to write out a detailed account of such experiments as led to the new colour, place it in a sealed envelope, write on the outside that it may be opened on a date so many years hence, and hand it to the Secretary of the Avicultural Society. F. Lort-Phillips, Major . Sir, --Referring to Major Lort-Phillips' letter in the February Magazine, a few notes I have may not be out of place. Re Apple-greens, the first was bred by Mrs. Ransom, of Wimbledon Park, in 1920, she called it a Jade (see my article in Bird Notes, 1920, page 152). She got some Blue-breds from me, and paired a hen to what she called a Bad Yellow, and bred the bird mentioned above. When I sent the description of it to the late Mrs. Dalton-Burgess she was very anxious to breed some, so I sent her the sister of Mrs. Ransom's hen and a Blue-tailed Yellow cock from a strain of Blue-tailed I had at the time. The following season both Mrs. Ransom and Mrs. Dalton-Burgess bred some very nice birds of the new colour. Mrs. Ransom gave up

Correspondence keeping birds, and Mrs. Dalton-Burgess and I got all her Jades and Jade-bred ; they very soon bred true to colour. Mrs. Dalton-Burgess did not think the name " Jade " was suitable, so we decided to call them " Apple-greens Re Blues in Great Britain, I think Mr. Pelham-Sutton was the first to breed Blues from a pair of Blues, and left the lag on 31st December, 1912. Mr. Pulsford, of Paignton, appears to have been the first to breed Blues from a pair of Blue-bred Greens, 9th February, 1914. The origin of the Blue is unknown, and it is no good guessing at it, but the Kev. J. M. Paterson came very near producing them by selection and semi-dark aviaries (see article by him in Bird Notes , page 216, vol. 1912), but I believe he left this country and parted with his birds before complete success. I was the first to produce them from a Blue- bred Green hen and selected Common Green cocks. In 1914 I got a Green hen from Mr. Pulsford (I have her pedigree). She was f blue, f green, J yellow. From her, paired to a selected Common Green cock, T bred one Green hen only. In 1915, from the Pulsford hen and another selected Common Green cock, I bred four Green cocks. In 1916 I selected one of these cocks and paired him to his half- sister (the hen bred 1914) ; they produced two Blues and one Green. Before this the only Blue I had seen was the cock of the first pair given to the Zoo by M. Pauwel. I may mention that my Blues were much darker than the one at the Zoo, but they were pure Blue and pure White. Re Whites, I think Mr. Astley or Mr. Hebb was the first to breed a White. Mr. Astley's was bred in an aviary containing Blues, Yellows, and Greens, so the pedigree will never be known. I think Mr. Hebb's bird was bred from two Blues. Mr. Bradshaw bred the third White from a pair of Blue-bred Greens he got from me (see Cage Birds ,
algorithms.reference: 6th December, 1924). Mrs. Dalton-Burgess bred the first Mauves from the first Cobalts that came into England, and Madame Lecallier bred them in France about the same time and in the same manner. John W. Marsden,
algorithms.figure: Correspondence
algorithms.bodyText: Sir, -- I have just had an amusing proof that the propensity for mimicry in Parrots is not confined to vocal expression. As my aviaries are being taken down for removal there is much hammering on wood, wire, and corrugated iron constantly going on, as the carpenters engage in their work. These dulcet sounds my old Grey obviously considers to be worthy of reproduction, but as they are beyond the compass of her voice, extensive though it be, she has to resort to instrumental methods to obtain the desired result. On going up to her aviary the other morning, I was surprised to hear the typical sounds of carpentering proceeding therefrom, though no human agent was in view. Looking inside, I saw the Parrot with her head bent right over, giving her perch five or six hard taps with the culmen of her beak, and then turning to one side and repeating the action on the wire and iron to produce the necessary variation in sound. The time and rhythm were perfect in each case ! Tavistock.

Sir, --Mr. Porter's timely and interesting article on the Quezal, the only sensational species of the larger birds that has not been imported alive, reminds me to record the importation alive of one of the few sensational small birds. This is the Cape Sugar-bird (Promerops cafer), a species resembling a Bulbul in size and colouring--brown with yellow patch under tail, with the bill of a Sunbird and the long flowing tail of the Giant Whydah (Coliuspasser proone). Before the w'ar I saw a fine specimen of this striking nectar-feeding bird in the care of Mr. W. Frost, who was keeping it for some one, as I understood ; it was never exhibited, so far as I know. With regard to the threatened extermination of the Quezal, I should like to draw attention to the fact that, according to an article in La Nature in January, 1928 (I think), a similar fate menaces the Kagu, and a far more certain one, as it is flightless or nearly so. Neglected dogs preying for themselves are the cause. F. Finn.

Sir, --The Snowy Owls, about which I wrote in the Avicultural Magazine in 1929, p. 18, have been showing further changes. The big bird that I take to be the hen is now all white on the head and neck, except for a band of spots across the forehead, but she retains full markings elsewhere. The white bird appears to be going back a bit; he always had a few markings at the end of his wings, and now, I think, he has more. The other two, which are not now in the collection, were much alike as I last remember them--nearly all white, but still showing many small markings in places ; so one had speeded up in his progress towards whiteness. It is evident that the method and speed of the assumption of whiteness in this Owl varies with the individual, in males at any rate. F. Finn.

Sir, --All Pheasant fanciers must have been deeply interested in Mr. Van Heyst's letter in the March issue of our Magazine, detailing the results of his Pheasant breeding during recent years. In my opinion articles and letters dealing with Pheasants are all too few and far between, but possibly the average Pheasant fancier is so. absorbed in his hobby as to forget that others also who are interested would like an occasional article or at least a letter. I may be prejudiced, but can there be a more fascinating and intriguing hobby than breeding and rearing fancy Pheasants of various breeds. The rearing of such well-known breeds as Silvers, Goldens. Amhersts, and Reeves is comparatively easy, but when one tackles rearing such breeds as the Bornean Fireback, Impeyan, Peacock Pheasant and the Elliot then one indeed is faced with problems, perplexities and anxieties w 7 hich however only serve to enhance such successes as we achieve. What an absorbing hobby it is. I am quite certain that many aviculturists, who now specialize only in such small birds as Budgerigars, Finches, etc., would soon become so engrossed in their Pheasants as possibly even to neglect their smaller pets. For
algorithms.figure: Correspondence
algorithms.bodyText: apart altogether from their wonderful and majestic beauty--I use the word majestic without hesitation--it is so entertaining to study the eccentricities of the young birds. Their habits are so entirely dis- similar, for instance one finds the Impeyan chick cheekily bold, very tame and always busily digging with his upper mandible for grubs and worms, whereas the Elliot chick one finds extraordinarily shy, wary and apparently never ready for artificial food. And then the final wonder when one watches the growing male bird gradually assuming his gorgeous plumage, some in the first year, others in the second. Does one experience the same variety of interests in breeding smaller birds ? I commenced writing this letter with the firm determination to deal only with Mr. Van Heyst's breeding results, but, as usual, when I commence writing of Pheasants my pen runs away with my good resolutions. One cannot help being struck with the varied success Mr. Van Heyst has had. The fertility of the eggs has been uniformly good with the exception of his Crossoptilons in 1928. It would be interesting to learn from Mr. Van Heyst whether he discovered the cause for so many infertile eggs in that year. Are one year birds infertile ? Why is it Tragopans are so very difficult to breed ? I note his hen Satyr in 1928 laid 11 eggs, not one of which was fertile. This strikes me as amazing for I have found the Tragopan by no means delicate, in fact the very opposite. One can readily understand the eggs of the Bornean Fireback being infertile as of course'their native habitat is very hot and humid, but last year I incubated 15 eggs of this breed of which 14 were fertile and 12 hatched. Mr. Van Heyst's hatching was quite good with the exception of Horsfields. I note he reared two Impeyans out of 9 chicks hatched. I hatched 13 chicks out of 14 eggs, but I will draw a discreet veil over my rearing results. Mr. Van Heyst is to be congratulated on his very successful rearing of Crossoptilons and Swinhoes. Of these two breeds he reared 51 out of 55 hatched. This is really remarkable and great credit is due to him. In conclusion may I thank Mr. Van Heyst for his most helpful

Correspondence statistics, and I only hope that some other fancy Pheasant breeder will take the hint. Mr. George Beever occasionally gives ns an only too short but always interesting article on fancy Pheasants, so perhaps he will oblige us once more. I could also mention a lady who could write us a most illuminating article, perhaps this lady will soon do so. P. J. Lambert.

Sir, --In his interesting article on the breeding of the Sarus Crane Lord Rothschild says that he has been unable to find any record of complete success with this species during the past hundred years. Apparently the Woburn records have been overlooked. The Sarus was first bred there some time prior to 1908 and the A.S. Medal was awarded for the event. Writing on the Cranes at Woburn, the Duchess of Bedford says (Avicultural Magazine, 1920, p. 167) " For many years previous to the war these Cranes nested and often reared their young." A. A. Prestwich.
