algorithms.sectionHeader: THE Avicultural Magazine BEING THE JOURNAL OF THE AVICULTURAL SOCIETY FOR THE STUDY OF FOREIGN & BRITISH BIRDS IN FREEDOM & CAPTIVITY
algorithms.bodyText: Fifth Series- --Vol. VIII.--No. 6 .--All rights reserved. JUNE, 1930.

The name Plantain-eater is applied to certain of the Touracos, amongst which are the two species of the genus Musophaga which are distinguished by the upper part of the bill being swollen and forming a horny sheath which extends on to the forehead. The subject of the present note and of the accompanying plate, M. violacea, occurs in West Africa from Senegambia to the Cameroons, the other species, M. rossce, occurring in Angola and Equatorial Africa. Ross' Plantain-eater or Touraco was figured and described in this journal in December, 1910. The accompanying plate gives a very good idea of the Violaceous Plantain-eater, which is one of the most' beautiful of birds and a thoroughly desirable subject for aviculture. The red cap on the head \0x25A0consists of upstanding short feathers, and has the appearance of velvet. In Ross' Plantain-eater these feathers are much longer and form an upstanding crest. In one of the outside aviaries of the Zoo Bird House, a pair of M. violacea disport themselves, and are generally regarded as the most beautiful birds in the whole collection. They have the red flight- feathers common to the majority of the Touracos and these present

Alex Hampe--In Search of Bare Chinese Birds a quite vivid spectacle as the bird flies and the sunlight is seen through them. They are birds of the forests, rarely coming to the ground, and feeding upon fruit and, probably to a certain extent, young green leaves. Also they probably eat insects and nestling birds in the wild state. D. S-S.
algorithms.sectionHeader: IN SEARCH OF RARE CHINESE BIRDS By Alex Hampe
algorithms.bodyText: Detesting the idea of being counted amongst the black sheep which Lord Tavistock mentions in his article of the February number of our Magazine, I hope the following lines about my experience in trying to get rare Chinese birds and to send them to Europe will be of interest to the reader. My first venture in this line was the Derbyan Parrakeet. Having read how very rare this Parrakeet is in Europe I went to the native city and tried to find some of them. I had many times seen them there in the bird shops, but as is often the case just when one particularly wants something it is hard to get it. After a few weeks' search I could only find three single cocks which had been in private possession and. of these a friend of mine acquired two, whilst I procured the remaining one and we finally landed them safely in England. But what I wanted were breeding pairs in the hope of reading later on an account of the breeding of this species in our Magazine. Consulting my special bird dealer, he told me that on account of the political disturbances in the Yangtze valley none would come any more to Shanghai, but finally he agreed to send a man to Chungking in Szechuan and bring me ten pairs. After being paid a considerable sum of money in advance my man departed. I waited patiently for two months, only to be disappointed by the reappearance of my man absolutely empty-handed. He had gone as far as Ichang and there met a lot of Chinese soldiers who treated him very badly and took his money from him, so he got very frightened
algorithms.title: Alex Hampe---In Search of Bare Chinese Birds
algorithms.bodyText: and returned to Shanghai. Well, my money was gone and I was still without the Parrots. I now wrote to a friend residing in Chungking and sent him a coloured plate of the Derbyan, asking him to kindly procure me some of these Parrots. After seven weeks I got a letter informing me that no Parrots were to be had in Chungking, that my request had, however, been passed on to a foreigner in Chengtu. Five weeks later I received further information that the gentleman in Chengtu had sent a catcher further inland who had succeeded in catching forty-three and bringing twenty-one safely to Chengtu. The others, much to my sorrow, had died when transporting them over the high mountain-passes. Patiently I waited for another five weeks, when to my intense joy my friend wrote me that six pairs were on the way to Shanghai, the others he had sold to Chinese in Chungking, as he thought that I did not want so many of these " noisemakers " as he called them. This was the end of February. March and April passed, but no Derbyan appeared, and I gave up hope of seeing them in Shanghai. Then on a very hot, sultry day in May, when I had just comfortably sat down in my softest easy chair after a copious race-tiffin, I heard a knock at my door. Rather annoyed on account of the disturbance, I opened, and to my great surprise found a Chinese sailor with four most miserable looking Derbyans. Each bird was fastened to the usual iron perch, and they were all as thin as threads. The sailor told me that the little steamer had run on a sandbank in the Yangtze, that they had a long delay on account of this accident, and that he finally proceeded by another steamer from Hankow. Now I had the Parrots, but in what condition ? Forgotten was my afternoon's rest. In no time I was in the Chinese city; bought cages, hemp and sunflower seed, and installed each Parrot in a separate cage. They at once started to eat hemp and sunflower seed greedily, and, as they were so very much run down, I left the electric light burning during the night for the next week, so that they could have a meal during night-times. During the next few weeks they greatly improved and very soon did let me know that they felt better by making a great deal of noise. When one started all the others fell in, and that very often at 5 o'clock in the morning. Knowing only too well what a bad passage one may encounter
algorithms.page: 144 Alex Uampe--In Search of Bare Chinese Birds
algorithms.bodyText: during July-August in the Indian Ocean, I intended to ship my birds at the beginning of September, but very soon my neighbours com- plained and, although I tried to pacify them, telling them that the birds were so rare and that their sing-song was really not so bad, I was soon politely informed by the manager of the hotel that either the birds or myself with the birds would have to go. So I ordered a cage and shipped my Derbyans on a very hot day in July. Great was my joy when, after about two months, I received a letter from Mr. Seth-Smith informing me that all my Derbyans had arrived in good condition and had already found good homes. I am sorry to say so far none have bred, but I sincerely hope that next autumn we will read an account of the Derbyan having bred in England. Another lot of ten pairs which I had ordered from Chengtu, as I had some further inquiries from India and Japan for Derbyans, was sent off for me from Chungking in June, 1928, and escaped in Ichang, but finally six birds were recaptured and reached Shanghai in November. They have also found their way into the aviaries of some prominent Japanese and French fanciers. This year I have only seen one single cock in our bird market, which had been brought down privately. Already in pre-war time it had been my great ambition to get some of the rare Chinese Pheasants, such as blue and white Crossoptilons, Temminck's Tragopans, Chinese Monauls, etc. I offered high prices to different bird dealers and supplied them with coloured plates which they could send into the interior, but all my efforts were in vain. Then about two years ago I made the acquaintance of a Chinese dealer who formerly did a large business in fancy feathers. Knowing that years ago a good many of the tail-feathers of the blue Crossoptilon were exported (by the way under the name of Grue de Numidie), I showed him a picture of the bird and asked him whether he could obtain some live birds for me. He said he would try, but it would be very difficult, as he had to send a man to Kansu, to which province there is no connection by rail or water. A few days after our conversation he appeared again in my office and told me he was willing to send a man, provided I paid him #50 in advance and agreed to a certain price for every bird he would bring alive to Shanghai. This price was of course exorbitantly high,
algorithms.title: Alex Hampe--In Search of Bare Chinese Birds
algorithms.bodyText: but after some bargaining we came to an agreement and tbe dealer and myself signed a formal contract. This was in August, 1928 ; month after month went by and I heard nothing more of my dealer until in February, 1929, he turned up again with the agreeable news that his man was on his way to Hankow with twenty-eight birds. I waited another three months, and finally on the 6th May, the very same day I had received my Derbyans a year ago, the Crossoptilons arrived. They were packed in six large baskets in which they had been carried for nearly six months by kulis and donkeys up to Hankow. Ordinarily the journey from Kansu to Hankow takes only about two months, but on account of the revolt of the Mahomedans in Kansu and of so many bandits and robbers being about, my man had often to wait for weeks in villages for a protected caravan with which he could proceed further. From Hankow he went, of course, by steamer. Notwithstanding the long journey the Pheasants were in good health. They were, of course, rather dirty and their tail feathers were all cut, but when I had installed them in a large aviary which I had constructed in my stable and provided them with plenty of sand, they soon improved. I gave them a mixture of minced beef and bran in the morning, paddy and hemp in the after- noon, and greenstuff ad lib. They were all very tame from the beginning and would feed from my hand. During the next few days I made, however, a very unpleasant discovery, namely, that the flock consisted mostly of cocks. This, according to my experience, is so often the case with gallinaceous wild-caught birds. I have often seen wild Golden Pheasants in our bird market in quantities, but amongst fifty birds there was very often not a single hen. After careful examination I came to the conclusion that I had only two certain hens. A few weeks later one proved her sex by laying three large eggs and the other one I saw pairing with a cock. These were surely signs of well-being, and I therefore decided to despatch my birds. Four were finally safely landed in Japan, eighteen in France, and one went to the Zoo of London. Let us hope that the two hens are still alive and will prove prolific mothers of many little Crossoptilons, so that Europe will be the richer by a handsome and interesting Pheasant.

Sydney Porter--Notes on the Birds of Dominica I am now after the white Crossoptilon which lives in Tibet, and have great hopes to see specimens in Shanghai during this year. If my hopes materialize I will put a white Crossoptilon feather in my cap and walk through the streets of Shanghai one of the proudest men of the Far East.
algorithms.sectionHeader: NOTES ON THE BIRDS OF DOMINICA
algorithms.bodyText: (Concluded from page 126 ) " Siffleur de Montagne " or the Solitair ( Myadestes dominicanus). --Deep in the heart of the mountain forests one meets with this remark- able bird, but alas, it is seldom seen, though upon one occasion I did catch sight of a bird and watched it for a time. It is the one creature which impresses the rare travellers who penetrate into its home ; for in the stillness and the gloom one hears proceeding out of the dense undergrowth a series of the most remarkable aud clear notes which at once arrest the ear and call one to attention. This wonderful songster is about the size of a small Thrush and of a beautiful pearl-grey colour marked with chestnut, black and white. Gosse has written extensively on this bird or rather an allied species in his Birds of Jamaica. After the Mozambique Shrike I know of no bird with such remarkable vocal powers. Perhaps I may be forgiven for quoting a short piece from a very rare and ancient book which I had the good fortune to pick up recently, Thomas Attwood's History of the Island of Dominica, which book contains many interesting and quaint descriptions of the mammals and birds of the island. " The mountain whiftler is of the size of an Englifh lark and is remarkable only for its loud charming whittle, which refembles the human voice in the melodious notes; but which the bird varies in a moft aftonifhing manner." Again we read from the same source " What is remarkable of the finging birds of this country is, that they lofe their finging faculties when taken, pine away and die, notwithftanding the greateft attention

Sydney Porter--Notes on the Birds of Dominica 147 is paid to them." Evidently in those days the science of Aviculture was little understood. Antillean Cuckoo (Coccyzus minor shelleyi ).--These are quiet unobtrusive birds which creep about the bushes and undergrowth. I once watched a pair of these birds, the cock was feeding the hen with hairy caterpillars and every time he brought her one he jumped on to her back and dropped it into her wide open mouth. The plumage of these birds is exceedingly loose and fluffy, and is continually blown about by the slightest breeze. The birds make a series of strange sounds which are very unbirdlike, in fact they are almost identical with the sounds made by the Senegal Coucal, a bird with which I was familiar in Africa ; these sounds consist of a series of loud deep " ohs " which get faster and sound somewhat like water running out of a long-necked bottle and sometimes the bird makes a sound like a door on rusty hinges slowly opening and shutting. Often the birds would come around the house to feed upon the large hairy caterpillars which abounded, and their strange cries were one of the characteristic sounds of that region. I spent many pleasant hours seated under the great trees near the house watching these charming birds, which were quite fearless. They would come within a few yards and take an intelligent interest in what I was doing ; suddenly they would appear quite close to one and remain so until one took one's eyes off them, then they disappeared as silently as they came. These Cuckoos are exceedingly beautiful in a quiet way and were quite my favourite birds in Dominica. The good they do in destroying harmful caterpillars which no other birds will eat must be inestimable. Their plumage is a striking arrangement of soft brown, black, white and grey, the feathers being exceedingly soft and silky. Ani (Crotophaga ani). --A very strange-looking bird, more like a miniature Hornbill and yet it is related to the Cuckoos. It is to be seen usually where cattle pasture, attracted no doubt by the flies, and it is also to be seen by the road sides where the mountain streams trickle over them. One always sees these birds in little companies of about six or seven, and they always keep surprisingly close to each other. In fact, I have never come across such a gregarious bird ; they
algorithms.page: 148 . Sydney Porter--Notes on the Birds of Dominica
algorithms.bodyText: reminded me more of the Touracos than any other birds, having the same gregarious habits and the same peculiar undulating flight, and by following one behind the other when flying from one tree to another. Members of a flock are seldom more than a few feet from one another, but often a couple will steal a few moments and fly to an adjoining tree, there to perform a mutual toilet. In the lovely valley near the house I occupied I once saw rather an amusing incident, two such birds as mentioned above were preening each others' feathers when a big old fellow much larger than the rest of the flock, and who was sitting not far away, evidently felt jealous, so he flew on to the backs of the devoted couple and with a lot of pushing gradually wheedled his way in between the two birds. They made no objection, and as soon as he had settled down they commenced to give him a very thorough and none too gentle toilet. With scrupulous care each bird did one side of him, commencing at the beak and gradually going down to the tail. The old bird seemed to have got what he came for and in a few minutes flew off and the two other birds at once sidled up to each other again and went on love-making. Perhaps the old bird was either the mother or father-in-law who came to receive what was due from bis children ! These birds can teach us humans a few lessons, for I have never seen groups of birds so solicitous towards each other's welfare as these are, and though they are always in the closest proximity they never seem to quarrel. No bird in the West Indies made a greater appeal to me than this one, partly, I think, owing to the great comrade- ship shown to one another. The Ani is not, I believe, a native of the Lesser Antilles, but was introduced many years ago from Jamaica and Cuba. It is one of the most valuable birds in the West Indies to the farmers and planters, for it consumes enormous quantities of obnoxious insects. It also follows cattle, settling on their backs and picking off the flies and ticks. These propensities are recognized, and the bird is protected in all the islands. Gosse states that these birds build a communal nest where five or six pairs of birds " bring forth and educate a common family ". The birds always have the appearance of being very shabby and dirty ; I don't know why it should be, perhaps it is because the colour of the
Sydney Porter--Notes on the Birds of Dominica

plumage is like that of an old faded black apron. Gosse also tells us that the huge beak is used for opening out the soft earth, etc. ; he says that " if a patch of cow's dung be examined after Crotophagas have been searching for the larvae, it will be found furrowed as if a miniature plough has passed through it ". Although I have never seen the bird doing this, the beak is usually very dirty and muddy as though the bird had been prodding about in the earth. Grey Thrush (Allenis fasca). --This sombre-looking Thrush is a very common bird around the old cultivated lands, but while a true Thrush I have never seen it on the ground. Though living around the country houses it is wild and shy and as soon as it sees that it is being observed it plunges into the dense bush. This Thrush has the sweetest and most mellow song of any bird of the Thrush family with which I am acquainted. It seems to feed principally upon the small insects which infest the lime-trees. " Trembleur " (Cinclocerthia rujicauda). --I know of no English name for this strange babbler-like bird. It is exceedingly common and simply courts attention. It takes the same place in Dominica as the Thrush does at home. It moves about in a very curious attitude, with the long tail held upright like a Wren's and the wings fluttering like those of a young bird expecting food. It has quite a fine song, too, something like that of the European Thrush. I have frequently seen it sipping the honey from the glorious scarlet flowers of a wonderful tree which seems to grow quite commonly in certain parts of the island. These trees seem to be the local rendezvous of the bird life in the district, most species seem to flock there to sip the honey, or if they don't imbibe the sweet liquid they find many insects which do. When paying a visit to a beautiful estate in the centre of the island I was very surprised to see these birds flying into the living veranda and pick up crumbs and other tit-bits, there they were absolutely fearless. One gets used to seeing small Einch-like birds coming in to a house, but to see these strange denizens of the tropics in such close contact with human beings was an unique sight. In colour this bird is various shades of rich brown and in size about as large as a Turtle Dove with a long slender beak. It is certainly one of the most striking looking birds which inhabit the Antillean Islands.
algorithms.title: 150 Sydney Porter--Notes on the Birds of Dominica
algorithms.author: Northern Water Thrush ( Seiurus noveboracensis noveboracensis).
algorithms.bodyText: --This bird is very un-Thrush-like indeed, and looks more like a glorified Pipit, which I suppose it is, being a kind of connecting link between the two families. I don't think that it has been recorded from Dominica before. It is a migrant from North America. It differs from the ordinary Pipit, for instead of having a dull whitish breast as most of them have, this bird is a beautiful lemon yellow on the underparts and in spite of being called a Thrush it appears to resemble the true Pipits in all its habits. I found these birds in pairs in the valley I have mentioned before, where they lived by the side of the drainage channels continually running up and down in their search for insects, but if disturbed they are quite ready to perch on the trees when occasion demands. Antillean Giant Kingfisher ( Ceryle alcyon). --An extremely showy bird when on the wing, but a very shy one which shuns the habitations of man. It frequents the deep and quiet reaches of the rivers where it can fish with ease. I should think this bird has a very easy living, for the rivers simply teem with fish. I have often seen it by the sea shore ; on a lonely but very beautiful palm-fringed beach where every day I used to bathe and have sun-baths lived a pair of these birds, and as soon as I got down I could discover where they were by their exceedingly loud and raucous cries. I rather fancy that they had a nest there, but so wary were they that I never discovered it, but I think that it was high up in the soft rock of the cliffs which closed in the little beach. Piviere's Buzzard (Buteo rivieri ).--There seem to be very few birds of prey in Dominica as far as I could make out and a pair of these fine birds lived in the river valley below the house where I resided for a time, and it was a sight that pleased me more than any other to see these grand birds floating high up in the celestial blue skies with outstretched motionless pinions, sweeping round and round in huge spirals, continually calling and answering one another with their loud and plaintive calls. The hen appears very much larger than the male when on the wing. I often came across the male of the pair which inhabited the district, when riding in the valleys. He appeared to be quite tame, and I often

Sydney Porter--Notes on the Birds of Dominica 151 used to watch, him within a few yards ; I would often disturb him on the ground or in a thick bush, but could never find out what he was doing; sometimes he would fly on to the stump of a tree and eye me over until I got too close, when he would throw himself into the air with the greatest ease and grace imaginable and sail off without a single motion of his huge pinions to join his mate in some other valley. In time the birds seemed to get used to my presence, and I have watched them both within a few yards feasting upon some small mammal or lizard, but I never saw them eating a bird. Caribbean Sparrow Hawk ( Falcocaribhaearum ).--My first introduc- tion to this lovely little Hawk was rather dynamic, for, riding one day along a rough track, a beautiful little male dashed almost under my horse's head and seized a lizard off the road, which it carried to a near-by tree and commenced to eat. These Hawks are not common birds by any means, in fact no birds of prey are common in the island. Little Green Heron ( Butorides virescens maculata). --I always had a particular affection for this jolly little chap because I so often caught him unawares, creeping in the shallows of the rivers, not like his larger cousins who always have their plumage compressed when fishing, but with his plumes loose and waving in the breeze. As soon as he caught sight of one, especially if one was very close up to him, he would seem rather confused and ashamed at having been caught off his guard ; he would hesitate and continue walking up-stream for a minute or two, always keeping his eye on me, but the second I took my eyes off him he was off in a flash, flying into a bush uttering his strange harsh croak, which is extremely loud for so small a bird. If I remained in the same spot perfectly quiet he would come back and with some hesitation would resume his fishing, which consisted of walking almost imperceptibly up the stream catching little fishes as he went. This little heron is extremely beautiful and would make an ideal aviary bird. I believe it is a migrant from North America. If anyone is interested in Herons I would advise them to read
algorithms.reference: Life Histories of North American Marsh Birds , published by the Smithsonian Institution of America ; it is one of the very best books
algorithms.page: 152 Sydney Porter--Notes on the Birds of Dominica
algorithms.bodyText: I have ever read on the Herons of North America--in fact all the books published by the Institute on bird life are very fine and quite inexpensive. Blue Heron (Florida ccerulea ccerulescens ).--By the side of the rushing boulder-strewn mountain rivers and streams one is sure to see this bird, usually in pairs, but the birds often work some distance apart from each other. I have often watched them wading in a rushing torrent that would almost have swept a strong man off his feet, but I suppose that the bird would grip the stones with its huge feet. There are few sights more beautiful than this Heron fishing in the indescribably lovely Dominican rivers, which are as clear as crystal and overhung with graceful palms, tree-ferns, and flowering trees ; every movement is grace as he slowly stalks along with his spotless plumage tightly compressed against his body. Sometimes he will rest and relax, shaking out his beautiful filamentous plumes until he seems completely enveloped in them. One of the strangest things about this Heron is that the young birds are for the first year pure white , and until I knew this I thought the birds were Egrets ; this is a most extraordinary thing, for in the case of most young birds the immature dress is usually of a protective nature until they have learnt the ways of the world ; but in this case it is the reverse, and I have noticed that the young birds are much shyer than the adults. The old birds are a uniform dark slate-blue. While in the white phase the birds are extremely shy and difficult to approach. In this plumage the birds look very beautiful and ethereal, and even more beautiful than the old birds, even though they lack the long plumes. I was told that there was a nesting colony of these Herons on the other side of the island, but I was never able to- get across to see it. Yellow-crowned Night Heron (Nyctanassa violacea). --The home of this Heron is in the mangrove swamps which are found all round the island ; it does not seem to frequent the freshwater streams like the other Herons and is mostly seen perched on the great aerial roots of the mangroves which often grow right out into the sea. It is a thick-set but very beautiful Heron, and very different in appearance to the other slim and graceful Herons of the island. It is one of the

Sydney Porter--Notes on the Birds of Dominica 158 few birds besides the Parrots and Pigeons which is sought after by the natives for food. The general colour of this bird is a light grey with longitudinal markings of black on the wings and back ; the head is adorned with a long crest of white feathers and the crown slightly tinged with yellow, but why the bird has the very foolish name of 44 violacea " I cannot make out, for there is not the slightest trace of violet in its plumage. The back is adorned with long filamentous plumes very different from the ordinary Heron. They are the same width the whole of their length, whilst those of the other Herons taper towards the point. These birds feed mostly on the large land crabs which abound in Dominica; the birds first break off the stalk-like eyes, when they have the crabs quite at their mercy: they then proceed to smash the thick and heavy shell by repeated blows from their very stout beak, which is like a pickaxe. The natives told me that they had frequently seen these Herons dead with the neck firmly grasped between the claws of a giant crab. I can quite believe this, for I have seen crabs with claws nearly as large as a man's hand. The native name for this bird is 44 Crabbier This is the wildest and the shyest of all the Herons I came across : the sight of a human being will send it miles away, and by no amount of stalking can it be found again. One comes across evidences of the bird's handiwork on nearly all the little palm beaches--the shells of crabs picked perfectly clean and very systematically broken up. I believe that it feeds on some of the large shell-fish too, for I have often seen collections of broken shells which no other creature would have had the strength to break up. I think that the ornithologist who named this bird 44 violacea " was either wearing blue glasses at the time or had been tasting some of the West Indian 44 mountain dew ", a tablespoonful of which is enough to make one see things in quite a different light! This species is not so nocturnal as would be imagined by its name, for it is only seen during the day. I believe there exists in Dominica a large and, I think, undescribed species of Heron which appears to be nocturnal. The natives say that it lives by day in the inaccessible forests on Morne Diablotin,
algorithms.page: 154 Sydney Porter--Notes on the Birds of Dominica
algorithms.bodyText: comes down to the sea-shore about six o'clock in the evenings to feed, and returns about midnight. Many natives have told me that they have seen it when they were fishing by torchlight about midnight. This bird has been minutely described to me by many natives and all the descriptions seem to coincide. I don't think that any white man has seen one. The natives told me that after the terrible hurricane of 1928 the birds ceased to be seen or to frequent the shores. Could it be that this was some rare and nearly extinct species which has now ceased to exist altogether ? Frigate Bird (Fregata aquila). --On the wing one of the most graceful birds in the world, it is lighter and more agile even than an Albatross, but on land one of the most ungainly birds that one could imagine. Sometimes one of these flying wanderers would come over from the other side of the island and stay for a few hours' fishing in our little palm-fringed bay. There is something very elusive and mysterious about these birds ; like the Albatross they just wander or rather glide on motionless wings around the tropics, belonging to no country in particular--a real wanderer with no home. Yellow-legged Sandpiper (Totanus flavipes ).--This jolly little bird is found by every river and stream in Dominica, where he may be seen running with great rapidity over the pebbles by the water's edge, wagging his stumpy tail in the same manner as a Pitta, and feeding upon the small crustaceans which abound there. Strange to say that, common as the bird is, I have never seen more than one bird in a given area. Right up in the mountain forests I have seen them wherever there is water, such as a fast-running mountain stream or river. These little " Yellow-legs ", as they are called in the States, are always quite tame, and very many pleasant hours I have spent by the side of a shady river watching my little friend and other water birds. The Antillean Ground Dove (Columbigallina passerina trochila). --A bird that is commoner and tamer than the Sparrows in Barbados, but in Dominica it is wild and unapproachable ; this is the same with all the Doves and Pigeons of the latter island, and is no doubt due to the constant persecution by the natives, who think them very toothsome morsels.
Sydney Porter--\0x25A0Notes on the Birds of Dominica

In Barbados they will almost take food from out of one's hand,, but here the sight of a human being will cause them to flee in abject- terror and, owing to this, they are very difficult to study. I do not- know whether these birds have been imported to England, but they would make very charming aviary birds and would be very easy to- capture, for the ones in Barbados could easily be caught with a butterfly net. These tiny Doves are usually to be seen feeding upon the small seeds round about the bare patches under the lime-trees, but in Bridge- town in Barbados they are to be seen in every garden and also in the- streets picking up crumbs, seeds, and all manner of vegetable food. The Antillean Dove (Zenaida castanea ).--Like the above bird this lovely Dove, which in the island of Barbados is exceedingly common and familiar, frequenting the gardens and main streets, is in Dominica excessively wild and shy, and this is due to the same reason that it is- much sought after as food by the natives, as in fact are all the Pigeons. It is a most lovely creature and one of the most beautiful Doves I know, certainly the most beautiful that inhabits the Antillean Islands. Its- strangely mournful call can be heard all over the island, a sound which, when heard in the distance, is particularly soothing. Once I came across a boy with three of these exquisite Doves, carrying them by a string tied to their legs, and they also had their wing-feathers cut. I asked him what he was going to do with them and he promptly replied that he was going to eat them, so I saved their lives by paying; sixpence each for them. About an hour afterwards he turned up again with another three. These poor creatures were purchased and the vendor soundly rated, I suppose with little or no effect! I kept them for a time, intending to bring them back to England, and when leaving the windward side of the island for Boseau I put them (owing to having, no other boxes or crates) in the crate containing my Parrots, but they so disturbed these latter birds and made such a mess of their food, that upon arriving in Roseau I gave them to a friend. I was sorry at having to part with them for, as I have said before, I think they" are one of the most beautiful of Doves. The metalic rose-pink colour of the neck is one of the most exquisite shades to be found i tl Nature.

Sydney Porter--Notes on the Birds of Dominica There were several other very rare ground Pigeons which inhabited the depths of the forests and these were even more shy than the two birds described above, and although I frequently put them up in my wanderings in the forests I was never able to get near enough to determine their species, but they no doubt belonged to either the genus Columba or Geotrygon. The Capped Petrel (CEstrelata hcesitata). --I have reason to think that this supposedly extinct bird may still exist in very small numbers on the island, for, when making a journey through the forest in search \0x25A0of another nearly extirpated species, A. imperialis , my guide asked me if I had ever heard of the Diablotin (the name under which the species was known), for he said that there were still some left upon the mountain, described them to me exactly, and finished up by saying that they had webbed feet and nested in holes in the rocks. He said that their haunts were almost inaccessible, and that they were never killed now because no one ate them. I mentioned this to several white people, including a well-known American naturalist who was doing some research work on the island, .and they ridiculed the idea. But I only hope that it may be true. It is very distressing to the naturalist to reflect upon the numerous species which have been exterminated since the advent of man in the West Indies. Hundreds of species are known to have vanished, and I dare say that there are many others from the smaller islands which have disappeared and left no trace behind. Many of these species were highly specialized and had no enemies, and were con- sequently very slow breeders, so that in a few years they were quickly disposed of by the men who settled on the islands, and I regret to say that the work of extermination is still being carried on, and in the next few years more will be added to the long list of vanished birds. I think that I can definitely say that the most recent to be added to the appalling list is the Black-billed or All Green Amazon of Jamaica (A. agilis), and in a few years' time I think that most of the Parrots and Pigeons from the various islands will join their deceased brethren. To get back to the Diablotin. It is stated in Newton's Dictionary of Birds that this bird has been exterminated by the introduction of a carnivorous marsupial into the island, but this is not so, as a further
Sydney Porter^Notes on the Birds of Dominica

extract from that interesting old book, Attwood's History of the Island of Dominica , will show :-- " The Diablotin fo called by the French, from its uncommonly ugly appearance is nearly the lize of a Duck, and is web-footed. It has a big round head, crooked bill like a hawk and large full eyes like an Owl. " Its head, part of the neck, chief feathers of the wings and tail, are black; the other parts of its body are covered with a milk-white down ; and its whole appearance is perfectly lingular. They feed on fifh flying in great flocks to the fea side in the night-time ; and in their flight make a difagreeable loud noife like Owls ; which bird they do alfo refemble, by their diflike of making their appearance in the day-time, when they are hid in holes in the mountains, where they are easily caught. This is done by ftopping up fome of the holes ; which lead to their hiding places and placing empty bags over the rest, which communicate under-ground with thofe ftopped; the birds at their ufual time of going forth to feek their food in the night- time, finding their pafiage impeded, make to the holes covered with the bags into which entering, they are immediately caught; and great numbers of them taken in that manner in a short time. " The flefh of the Diablotin is much admired by the French who ufed formerly to export great quantities of them falted to Martinique and other French islands; but the traffic was put a ftop to by the Legiflature of Dominica who, by an Act made for apprehending runaway negroes, prohibited the taking of thofe birds ; as before that time, the runnaways being numerous in the woods, furnifhed great quantities of them, for which they had in return, from fome ill-difpofed white people, mufkets, powder and balls ; which they made ufe of in murdering the Englifh inhabitants on the plantations." The Barbados Blackbird (Holoquiscalus fortirostris). --Before finishing this chapter on the birds of Dominica, I feel I must mention my old friend the Barbados Blackbird or, as he is known in the United States, the Purple Grackle, for even though he is not an inhabitant as far as I know of Dominica, he is a West Indian bird. No one fails to notice his glossy purple plumage and striking white eye, which misses very very little in the way of food.

Mrs. A. B. Black-- I know of no bird so characteristic of a country as this bird is of Barbados. He strikes the most casual visitor to the island, for he is everywhere along the roadsides ; in the cane fields when the cane is being cut he is almost under the very feet of the natives ; outside the hotels he is there with an eye on the main chance. When you are having a meal he will watch you like a hungry dog. In fact I cannot imagine Barbados without its Blackbirds. You never see him still: he is always hurrying about with that quick, business-like gait which characterizes the Starling family. I often wonder why they do not put his picture on the postage stamps. No wonder he is also called the Tinkling Grackle, for his metallic tinkle is heard every morning, noon, and evening from almost every tree in the island. This bird is indigenous to Barbados, but has been introduced to many of the other islands.
algorithms.sectionHeader: BREEDING THE GREEN-NAPED PHEASANT PIGEON IN CALIFORNIA
algorithms.bodyText: By Mrs. A. B. Black The Green-naped or Green-collared Pheasant Pigeon (Otidiphaps nobilis) is a native of Western New Guinea, and is a large and very beautiful Pigeon with iridescent plumage of bronzed wine-purple,, with black head, red beak, and red eyes. The legs and feet are straw- coloured and the toes rusty black. At the tarsal joint there are three shades of purple, a purple streak extending also the full length of the legs in both sexes, which becomes brighter in the nesting season. I find them the most interesting birds in my collection, but I had tO' study them for three years before I could persuade them to go to nest. I arranged nests in different positions and at different heights in the aviary, and they finally selected a low situation. They built their nest, with sticks in the same way as other Pigeons, and laid one egg of a light cream colour somewhat pointed at both ends. Incubation commenced, immediately the egg was laid.
algorithms.title: Breeding the Green-naped Pheasant Pigeon
algorithms.bodyText: Curiously enough, the incubation period takes twenty-three days in the case of a male chick and twenty-six days in the case of a female, and on three occasions has taken twenty-nine days on account of wind and unsettled weather. Neither egg or chick are visible until the latter is three weeks' old, the parents sitting very closely and in relieving one another one sits by the side of the other and the one that has been sitting gently slides off, the other sliding on, never allowing egg or chick to be uncovered. When the chick first becomes visible it is jet black, including eyes, beak, and legs, and the feathers give the appearance of a porcupine's quills. The female sits on the nest at night, the male relieving her at eight o'clock in the morning. He remains until twelve-thirty the next day, when she relieves him for half an hour. She again takes charge at five-thirty in the evening and remains on the nest for the night. They are the most affectionate birds I have ever seen at the nesting period. When they hear the young in the shell they both sit side by side with their bills together and their heads down close to the nest, and continue to act thus until the egg is hatched. The cock feeds the hen on the nest for the first week after hatching, she feeding the young bird. After this they relieve one another, as during incubation, until the young bird is able to leave the nest. At four months' old the baby is able to take care of itself. I have at present three breeding pairs. One pair of the younger breeders has at the time of writing a baby in the nest (10th April). The old original pair are now building their nest. I find that the first egg of the season produces a cock-bird, the next a hen ; so, by keeping a careful record of the eggs laid and hatched, I am able to tell the sex as each one appears, which is useful, as the sexes are exactly alike. Each pair of birds occupies a pen measuring 10 feet by 18 feet, covered with small-mesh wire netting, and alfalfa growing in the pen at all times. A pile of fresh cow manure is also kept in the pen to supply insect life, which they seem to require. Mixed Pigeon feed is fed and Barnes' Emulsion is given during the nesting period. The nest

Breeding the Green-naped Pheasant Pigeon is well dusted with, a mite powder we make ourselves, which keeps them free of mites, fleas, and other annoying insects, of which we have plenty in our warm Southern Californian climate. The enclosed picture is of a young female and her first baby, which is about four weeks old. You will note that they are mounted and that the peculiar feathering of the young bird is still noticeable, the legs and feet and bill being still black. Am enclosing a copy of a letter I received from Mr. E. W. Gifford, of 1650 Yista St. Oakland, California, which I wish you would incorporate with mine :-- " Dear Mrs. Black, There are three species of the Pheasant Pigeons belonging to genus Otidiphaps. Sometimes the term Pheasant Pigeon is applied to birds of the genus Macropygia , which are more correctly Cuckoo Pigeons. The Pheasant Pigeons of the genus Otidiphaps belong to the sub- family- of Pigeons called Geotrygeninae , the Partridge Pigeons or Quail Doves. The Green Collared Pigeon ( Otidiphaps noblis) which you are breeding is native to Western New Guinea and the island of Batanta. Your specimens are the only ones I know of in America. The White Collared Pheasant Pigeon ( Otidiphaps cervicalis) hails from South-Eastern New Guinea. The New York Zoological Park has one at present. The Eergusson Island Pheasant Pigeon (Otidiphaps insularis) is from the island of that name, one of the D'Entrecesteaux group, off the eastern end of New Guinea. I am writing the secretary of the Avicultural Society, London, proposing you for membership. With pleasant memories of our recent visit.
algorithms.reference: Sincerely yours, E. W. Gifford. 5 ' I might mention that we have the Cuckoo Pigeon mentioned in Mr. Gifford's letter.

algorithms.reference: Capt. G. Scott Hopkins--Fancy Pheasants
algorithms.bodyText: By Capt. C. Scott Hopkins With the permission of the Editor, I am taking this opportunity of giving a short account of my Fancy Pheasants. I am hoping that I may, by writing in this Magazine, encourage a few more bird-lovers to go in for Pheasants. Although so many of these beautiful birds come from hot climates, they are not, as*is thought by some people, delicate or difficult to keep. On the contrary, they are mostly very hardy and easy to keep. Of course there is a risk with freshly imported birds until they become acclimatized, but with ordinary care and attention they soon settle down and thrive. I prefer aviary-bred birds, and these are nearly always available, but with such birds as Tragopans and Firebacks there is sometimes a difficulty, and then one has to rely on imported stock. But a word of advice to anyone wishing to buy freshly imported Pheasants from dealers. Go and choose them yourself and as soon as you can after their arrival in this country. I speak from experience ! The beginner must not be down-hearted if he should lose a few now and then. It may be his own fault or just bad luck. Go on trying, and I will promise you your efforts will be rewarded. Providing you have suitable aviaries, either grass or gravel, that you feed them regularly with wheat, maize, and a little dari and plenty of green food winter as well as summer, there is no reason why they should not thrive and do well. I am not going to give a detailed account of how I keep my Pheasants, dimensions of aviaries, etc., etc., as I shall be taking up too much space, but I shall be very pleased to give what advice I can to anyone who is thinking of keeping these lovely birds. I have forty-eight aviaries, and keep about twenty-one varieties---
algorithms.reference: Chinese, Old English, Mongolian, Silver, Golden, Amherst, Reeves, Tragopan (Satyr), Monaul, Elliot, Bornean Fireback, Siamese Fireback, Vieillot Fireback, Melanistic Mutant, Peacock (Chinque's), Kaleeg (Nepal), Edward's, Imperial, Mikado, Swinhoe, Pure White Pheasant. I also have a pair of Californian Quail, Mexican Quail, Cuban Quail, Madagascar Partridges, Tree Partridges, and Burmese Jungle Fowl, which I guarantee pure. My aviaries are always open to anyone
algorithms.bodyText: Avicultural Notes who cares to come and see them. Several hundred people paid them a visit during last summer. I hope to have several young Pheasants to sell at the end of the breeding season.

The Minister of Health has prohibited the importation of Parrots into this country for the present, as from 20th May, the Order including all kinds of Parrots from all countries. This seems to be a very drastic move seeing that the only trouble has come from South American Parrots. Most of the European countries have also stopped the importation of Parrots generally, but the United States has only placed an embargo upon Parrots from South America. The con- sequence of this will be that the trade in Parrots will all be diverted to America. It would seem that those responsible for this drastic Order do not know one Parrot from another and have not taken the trouble to consult those who do know. They have presumably been advised entirely by the medical profession, and the fact that the doctors believe the disease which has been responsible for the death of some fourteen people in a population of over ten millions, to be traceable to Parrots is sufficient to convince them that Parrots must be banned from entering this country. But why on earth stop Lories and Cockatoos when the only Parrots accused of transmitting 'psittacosis are the Amazons ? Why make Australia and India suffer for the sins of South America ? Take the case of the Budgerigar. This is never nowadays imported from the country of its origin. It is now a domestic bird like the Canary in all European countries as well as in Japan, and all those that have been coming into this country within the last few years, and their number has been legion, have been captivity-bred birds. Why they should be accused of being disease carriers it is difficult to understand.
algorithms.figure: Correspondence
algorithms.bodyText: The effect of the embargo will be more serious than is generally realized, for not only will it mean loss to the importers of Parrots, but also to the manufacturers of cages and to the firms which specialize in the preparation and sale of Parrot foods.

Sir, --Dr. Karl Plath's Hanging Parrots would appear to be one of the subspecies allied to the Golden-backed--possibly Worcester's-- Loriculus worcesteri. The sexual distinction is as given. The destructive kabits of the Ringneck which visits Captain Hamilton Scott's garden are probably largely due to the fact that it is maintaining itself entirely *on natural food. Palceornis Parrakeets at liberty that are well fed on .seed and peanuts do not touch buds to any appreciable degree, nor do they damage flowers. They are, however, wastefully destructive among apples, as are the Tanygnathi , and need to be confined from June to October for that reason. Polyteline, Aprosmictine and the larger Platycercine Parrakeets are apt to be a bit hard on fruit-tree buds from the end of February to the end of April, and the two latter genera also eat ripe apples, but seldom do very serious damage. By having one's birds under control .at the feeding places it is quite easy to enjoy their beauty at liberty without any appreciable mischief being done to one's own or one's neighbour's gardens. It is not unusual for the Plum-headed Parrakeet to nest in a cage--I know of at least two instances--but the eggs are seldom fertile. Tavistock.

Sir, --The letter in the March issue of the Magazine concerning the attempted importation into the U.S.A. of the Cuban Tody was very interesting. The reason I am writing this letter is to throw a little light on the manner of obtaining " live food " when on board a ship, for this would seem rather a difficult problem unless one "is in the know " as we say in this part of the world.

Correspondence Several years ago I always had. great difficulty when trying to import delicate " softhills " into England which I had picked up on my travels until I found that the kitchens, pantries, and stores of nearly all ships simply swarmed with cockroaches, both large and small varieties. The first thing is to get to know the pantry steward, and then with the aid of " bakhsheesh " get him to set traps for these creatures in the warm places where they swarm. The trap is an easy matter. One takes a large tumbler, places a tablespoonful of coffee grains at the bottom, then smears butter, lard, or some other greasy substance all round the glass inside about an inch from the top : this allows the insects to get in, but they cannot get out again over the grease. Sometimes one will get half a tumblerful in a night, and these are greatly relished by all " softbills They are much better than mealworms. Sydney Porter.

Sir, --No doubt many readers who have kept Budgerigars in any numbers have noticed that their birds sing or warble--or whatever one may care to call it--after dusk and, in fact, quite late into the night when all else is silent. A still night with a gentle pattering rain seems to be the time when they become most vocal. It does not matter how dark it is or how late, and the whole company seem to join in, so that with just under a hundred birds, as I have at present, the volume of sound is very considerable, but not in the least objectionable. The following incident is, however, my excuse for penning these notes, and I shall be interested to hear if any members have had a similar occurrence. One of my cock Cockatiels has been singing at night. I think one is quite justified in calling their pretty spring trill and whistle a song, being quite a musical effort without any harsh or discordant notes. On most occasions it has been after I have gone to bed, and
algorithms.figure: Correspondence
algorithms.bodyText: curiously enough the Budgerigars nearby have been quite silent. Nor has the other cock Cockatiel in a neighbouring aviary attempted to join in. Some years ago I was puzzled by hearing at night a pretty but unfamiliar song, not unlike, but more full than, a Hedge Accentor's. It always seemed to come from the same spot and the singer was ultimately discovered to be a cock Snow Bunting in the aviary. I have never seen it recorded that this species sings at night, but of course his wild brethren at that period of the year--May--would be nesting in the far North, many miles from human habitation. Hamilton Scott.

Sir, --I have just returned from a second round trip to the West Indies. Although bird life is plentiful upon the various islands specimens are hard to obtain, for catchers and sellers appear to concentrate solely upon the various species of Parrots, Macaws, and Parrakeets. I managed to obtain a magnificent Troupial in Trinidad, and have got him home safely. I also purchased in the Slobbock Market at Demerara two Kudari birds. Up to now I can get these birds to eat no soft food other than bread and milk, the diet used and recommended by their previous owners. Of course, fruit in large quantities is included in their dietary. These birds were sheltered in the kitchen of the ship during the last ten days of the voyage, as the weather was extremely sunless and cold. They are all alive at the moment of writing, but I would greatly appreciate advice from more experienced members as to their proper treatment. In the Museum at Demerara I noticed a large cage containing some small birds. Upon the cage was displayed the following notice :-- "It is against the law to keep these little birds in captivity, but these specimens were taken from bad cruel boys who had trapped and caged them. As they could now no longer find their own food if set at liberty we keep them here out of kindness. Always be kind to dumb animals." If only catchers would interest themselves with smaller fry than

Correspondence the Parrot tribes there would doubtless be some beautiful and enter- taining specimens exported to England. There is the glossy black fellow, with the golliwog eyes like the Black-cheeked Parrakeet, which flies about the streets of Trinidad, a bird resembling a black Starling somewhat. Then there is his near relative, a smaller black bird of the same type, but without the golliwog eyes, which struts about the streets of St. Vincent. I missed a magnificent pair of young St. Vincent Parrots,reared from the nest, because owing to the recent parrot-fever our Captain had forbidden Parrots being brought aboard. I saw many species of Humming-birds flying in the gardens of houses situated in the various towns. The West Indian and South American birds appear to have much less fear of man than their European brethren. At St. Vincent the grey Mocking Bird was conspicuous, and could be both heard and seen. At Barbados in the bush near the Swimming Club birds were plentiful. I am not sufficiently educated to identify them.

Correspondence
algorithms.bodyText: Blue/Grey wing ; Laurel/Blue/Grey wing ; and Green/Blue/Grey wing. From these I hoped to breed Greywing-blues next year. The parents of the Blue cock 7, I was told, bred Whites in the same nest. In 1928 I mated him to the Blue hen 20, and out of 18 eggs in three nests she reared 5 Whites and 12 Blues. In 1929, as shown in the pedigree, I mated him to the Green/Blue hen 14, out of 19 eggs she reared 2 Greywing-green/Blues, 5 Blues, and 9 Green/Blues. These Whites and Greywings were apparently due to the Blue cock 7 : because the Blue hen 20 in 1929 mated to the Mauve cock 60 out of 20 eggs reared 16 Cobalts. And the Green/Blue hen 14 mated first to a Green/Blue cock 13 and afterwards to an Olive/Mauve 24 in three nests 1928 reared out of 21 eggs, 2 Cobalts, 2 Blues, 9 Laurels, and 5 Greens. Whilst I was away from home for a couple of days the attendant heard a row going on in the breeding pen and found the Cobalt hen 296 had killed the youngest of the Grey wing-blues : it was just old enough to tell that it was a Grey wing, but not whether it was a Grey wing-blue or Greywing-cobalt. The hen was covered with blood : she had gone quite crazy and had scalped her youngster and was trying to kill the others, but was- removed in time to save them from any damage. The cock bird is now feeding the others, and as one of them is already out in the flight I hope he will not have to labour alone for long. F. Lort-Phillips (Major). A DEATH FROM OLD AGE Sir, --Despite the not infrequent expression of opinions of a contrary nature it is a rare thing for an aviculturist to lose a bird from down- right old age and nothing else. There are comparatively few people who do not enormously under-estimate potential avian longevity, so that if a bird dies suddenly after what appears to them to be the normal span of the life of the species, they put it down to " old age " even though a post-mortem examination would have revealed some very definite disease or injury. Insufficiency of exercise, especially when combined with a faulty diet, will, in a longer or shorter period.

Correspondence induce a condition of all-round debility, but this premature breaking down of a bird's system, although it may be accompanied by many of the symptoms of old age, cannot be regarded as a really genuine example of the phenomenon. Until recently I cannot honestly say that a single bird in my collection has ever passed from full vigour to decline and death from pure old age. Some four specimens have died wholly or mainly from age, but all were markedly senile and on the downward path when I received them. The death last week of a cock Princess of Wales' Parrakeet after a residence of about sixteen years in my collection was therefore, very interesting to me as the first definite case I have had the chance of observing of a bird which has grown old under good conditions and has died naturally. What age the Parrakeet may have been when I received him I cannot say. I believe he was aviary-bred in Australia, which may account for the fact that he was never a very fine specimen, being small and of poor colour, with washed-out tips to the longer tail-feathers. For several years he was mated to a Crimson-wing, and after one or two initial failures succeeded in rearing two hybrids, the survivor of which has often appeared on the show bench. In 1927 and 1928 the Princess of Wales' proved infertile. In 1929 I did not use him for breeding and last autumn he did not moult properly. As the winter advanced he became very lame, and although he recovered from the weakness or injury he remained thenceforward abnormally inactive. Most of the day he spent sleeping. Like a sick bird he kept his head " under his wing " and both feet on the perch, but unlike a sick bird he often stretched himself and his appetite and digestion remained as good as ever. His power of flight was retained to the end. The last morning he came out of the shelter when the slide was raised, but soon went back again. At 11 o'clock he was sleeping peacefully in the sun but was obviously failing, and when I went to look at him after lunch he was dead. I sent the body to the Eoyal Veterinary College, but careful expert examination failed to reveal any evidence of disease. Time had dealt very gently with the old fellow : his actual passing had been quick and the period of preparation, though long, had been quiet and peaceful. Tavistock.
